qas.question: Who were not identified by name on the census before the civil war?
Who was Thomas Jefferson in a relationship with?
Not recognizing white fatherhood for multiracial slave children cause what to be lost?
Who will not reveal full ancestral data to mixed race people?

plausible_answers.text: people of mixed African-American and Native American descent

qas.question: What people report having elder family members who were open with genealogical information?

plausible_answers.text: Tracing the genealogy of African Americans

qas.question: What is usually a very easy process?
What identified slaves by name before the American Civil War?
Who acknowledged their mixed-race slave children in records?
Who was John Adams in a relationship with?

context: Sometimes <b4_0>people of mixed African-American and Native American descent<b4_0/> report having had <a3_0>elder family members<a3_0/> withholding pertinent genealogical information. <b5_0>Tracing the genealogy of African Americans<b5_0/> can be a very difficult process, as <b6_0>censuses<b6_0/> did not identify <a0_0>slaves<a0_0/> by name before the American Civil War, meaning that most African Americans did not appear by name in those records. In addition, many <b7_0>white fathers<b7_0/> who used slave women sexually, even those in long-term relationships like Thomas Jefferson's with <a1_0><b8_0>Sally Hemings<b8_0/><a1_0/>, did not acknowledge their mixed-race slave children in records, so <a2_0>paternity<a2_0/> was lost.
